text:
Introduction: After an unequivocal experience of the inefficiency of the present system, it is evident that we need a new Constitution. I propose, in a series of papers, to discuss various aspects of this issue: 

1. The utility of the Union to your political prosperity.
2. The insufficiency of the present Confederation to preserve that Union.
3. The necessity of a government at least equally energetic with the one proposed to achieve this goal.
4. The conformity of the proposed Constitution to true principles of republican government and its analogy to your own State constitution.
5. The additional security which its adoption will afford to the preservation of that species of government, liberty, and property.

I shall endeavor to provide satisfactory answers to all objections raised against it that may seem worthy of attention. Although some might think it superfluous to offer arguments proving the utility of the Union—indeed a point deeply engraved on the hearts of many—the fact is that dissenting voices are already whispering in private circles about the need for separate confederacies due to the perceived excessive extent of the thirteen States.

This doctrine will likely be gradually propagated until it gains enough supporters to be openly avowed. Nothing could be more evident to those who can take an enlarged view of the subject than the alternative: either adopt the new Constitution or face the dismemberment of the Union. Consequently, I shall begin by examining the advantages of that Union and the certain evils and probable dangers each State will encounter from its dissolution. This will constitute the subject of my next address.

I have aimed to put you on guard against attempts to influence your decision in a matter of utmost importance through impressions other than those resulting from evidence of truth. I must confess that, after careful consideration, I am convinced it is in your interest to adopt this Constitution. I believe this is the safest course for your liberty, dignity, and happiness. I make no pretense of deliberation where my decision has already been made. My motives rest within me, but my arguments are open for all to judge in a spirit that will not disgrace truth itself.

text:
The Same Subject Continued: It is not a new observation that the people of any country (if, like the Americans, intelligent and well-informed) seldom adopt and steadily persevere for many years in an erroneous opinion respecting their interests. That consideration naturally tends to create great respect for the high opinion which the people of America have so long and uniformly entertained of the importance of their continuing firmly united under one federal government, vested with sufficient powers for all general and national purposes.

The more attentively I consider and investigate the reasons which appear to have given birth to this opinion, the more I become convinced that they are cogent and conclusive. Among the many objects to which a wise and free people find it necessary to direct their attention, that of providing for their safety seems to be the first. The safety of the people doubtless has various dimensions, but one significant aspect is the prevention of war. Fewer just causes of war will be given by a good national government than by several lesser governments, which in turn favors the safety of the people.

As to those just causes of war which proceed from direct and unlawful violence, it appears equally clear to me that one good national government affords vastly more security against dangers of that sort than can be derived from any other quarter. Such violences are more frequently caused by the passions and interests of a part than of the whole; of one or two States than of the Union. Not a single Indian war has yet been occasioned by aggressions of the present federal government, feeble as it is; but there are several instances of Indian hostilities having been provoked by the improper conduct of individual States, who, either unable or unwilling to restrain or punish offenses, have given occasion to the slaughter of many innocent inhabitants.

The neighborhood of Spanish and British territories bordering on some States and not on others naturally confines the causes of quarrel more immediately to the borderers. The bordering States, if any, will be those who, under the impulse of sudden irritation and a quick sense of apparent interest or injury, will be most likely by direct violence to excite war with these nations; and nothing can so effectually obviate that danger as a national government, whose wisdom and prudence will not be diminished by the passions which actuate the parties immediately interested.

But not only fewer just causes of war will be given by the national government, but it will also be more in their power to accommodate and settle them amicably. They will be more temperate and cool, and in that respect as well as others, will be more in capacity to act advisedly than the offending State. The pride of states, as well as of men, naturally disposes them to justify all their actions and opposes their acknowledging, correcting, or repairing their errors and offenses. The national government, in such cases, will not be affected by this pride but will proceed with moderation and candor to consider and decide on the means most proper to extricate them from the difficulties which threaten them.

Besides, it is well known that acknowledgments, explanations, and compensations are often accepted as satisfactory from a strong united nation, which would be rejected as unsatisfactory if offered by a State or confederacy of little consideration or power. In the year 1685, the state of Genoa having offended Louis XIV., endeavored to appease him. He demanded that they should send their Doge, or chief magistrate, accompanied by four of their senators, to France, to ask his pardon and receive his terms. They were obliged to submit to it for the sake of peace. Would he on any occasion either have demanded or received the like humiliation from Spain, or Britain, or any other powerful nation?

Queen Anne, in her letter dated July 1, 1706, addressed to the Scottish Parliament, commented on the significance of the Union being formed between England and Scotland. Her observations are noteworthy as she highlighted that a complete and perfect union would lay a solid foundation for lasting peace. It was expected to secure religion, liberty, and property; remove internal animosities and inter-kingdom jealousies; enhance strength, wealth, and trade; and unite the island in affection, free from differing interests, thereby enabling it to resist all enemies.

Queen Anne urged calmness and unanimity in this significant affair, emphasizing that only through union could present and future happiness be secured and enemy designs thwarted. She noted that internal weakness and divisions invite external dangers, suggesting that unity and strong governance are crucial for security.

The history of Great Britain offers lessons on the pitfalls of division despite common interests. Despite being one island, its people were divided into three nations often embroiled in conflicts due to external manipulation, which kept mutual jealousies inflamed. This historical context warns against a similar fate if America divides itself into multiple nations, as it would likely incite jealousy and discord rather than unity.

The proposal for several confederacies in America is fraught with potential issues. No arrangement can ensure long-term equality among them; disparities in governance could lead to power imbalances. The most northerly confederation might grow more formidable, evoking the same tensions historically seen between northern and southern Europe.

Historical examples suggest that alliances between such independent entities would be ineffective or unfaithful due to differing interests and commercial needs. In America's case, as in Europe, neighboring nations with opposing interests often supported different sides during conflicts. The greater threat for American confederacies might stem from each other rather than distant powers, increasing reliance on foreign alliances for protection.

Ultimately, dividing America into independent sovereignties could make it vulnerable to foreign interference and hostilities. Historical precedents of Roman-like conquests under the guise of alliances serve as cautionary tales against such fragmentation. Thus, unity is deemed essential for security against external threats.

It discusses the problem of factions within a republican form of government and argues for the benefits of a large republic, particularly the United States as it was being structured under the new Constitution at the time.

### Key Points

1. **Definition of Faction**:
   - A faction is defined as a group of citizens with interests contrary to the rights of others or the community's overall interests.

2. **Causes and Remedies**:
   - The causes of factions are deeply rooted in human nature and cannot be removed without destroying liberty.
   - However, their effects can be controlled through various means, such as controlling the faction itself (not feasible in a free society) or removing its causes by ensuring uniform opinions.

3. **Advantages of Large Republics**:
   - In larger republics, there is a greater variety of parties and interests, making it less likely for a single majority to form with common motives against minority rights.
   - Representatives are more likely to be enlightened and virtuous in a large republic due to broader constituencies.

4. **Comparison between Republic and Democracy**:
   - A republic can better control factions compared to a democracy by using elected representatives who refine and enlarge public views.
   - A large republic offers advantages over a small one because it encompasses a wider variety of interests, making unjust majorities less likely.

5. **Union vs. States**:
   - The Union provides more security against factions than individual states due to its size and diversity.
   - Issues confined to single states are less likely to spread across the entire nation.

6. **Federalism as a Solution**:
   - The structure of the United States under the proposed Constitution (the Federalist system) offers remedies for factional issues inherent in republican governments.

### Conclusion

Madison argues that while factions cannot be eliminated, their effects can be mitigated through the establishment of a large republic and a federal system. This structure dilutes the power of any single faction by diversifying interests across a broad geographic area, thus protecting against tyranny by majority rule. The essay emphasizes the importance of maintaining a balance between local governance (states) and overarching national governance (federal government) to manage the challenges posed by factions effectively.

text:
The Same Subject Continued with a View to Economy

AS CONNECTED with the subject of revenue, we may with propriety consider that of economy. The money saved from one object may be usefully applied to another, and there will be so much the less to be drawn from the pockets of the people. If the States are united under one government, there will be but one national civil list to support; if they are divided into several confederacies, there will be as many different national civil lists to be provided for - and each of them, as to the principal departments, coextensive with that which would be necessary for a government of the whole. The entire separation of the States into thirteen unconnected sovereignties is a project too extravagant and too replete with danger to have many advocates. The ideas of men who speculate upon the dismemberment of the empire seem generally turned towards three confederacies - one consisting of the four Northern, another of the four Middle, and a third of the five Southern States. There is little probability that there would be a greater number. According to this distribution, each confederacy would comprise an extent of territory larger than that of the kingdom of Great Britain. No well-informed man will suppose that the affairs of such a confederacy can be properly regulated by a government less comprehensive in its organs or institutions than that which has been proposed by the convention. When the dimensions of a State attain to a certain magnitude, it requires the same energy of government and the same forms of administration which are requisite in one of much greater extent. This idea admits not of precise demonstration because there is no rule by which we can measure the momentum of civil power necessary to the government of any given number of individuals; but when we consider that the island of Britain, nearly commensurate with each of the supposed confederacies, contains about eight millions of people and when we reflect upon the degree of authority required to direct the passions of so large a society to the public good, we shall see no reason to doubt that the like portion of power would be sufficient to perform the same task in a society far more numerous. Civil power, properly organized and exerted, is capable of diffusing its force to a very great extent; and can, in a manner, reproduce itself in every part of a great empire by a judicious arrangement of subordinate institutions.

The supposition that each confederacy into which the States would be likely to be divided would require a government not less comprehensive than the one proposed will be strengthened by another supposition more probable than that which presents us with three confederacies as the alternative to a general Union. If we attend carefully to geographical and commercial considerations, in conjunction with the habits and prejudices of the different States, we shall be led to conclude that in case of disunion they will most naturally league themselves under two governments. The four Eastern States, formed all the causes that form the links of national sympathy and connection, may with certainty be expected to unite. New York, situated as she is, would never be unwise enough to oppose a feeble and unsupported flank to the weight of that confederacy. There are other obvious reasons that would facilitate her accession to it. New Jersey is too small a State to think of being a frontier in opposition to this still more powerful combination; nor do there appear to be any obstacles to her admission into it. Even Pennsylvania would have strong inducements to join the Northern league. An active foreign commerce, on the basis of her own navigation, is her true policy and coincides with the opinions and dispositions of her citizens. The more Southern States from various circumstances may not think themselves much interested in the encouragement of navigation. They may prefer a system which would give unlimited scope to all nations to be the carriers as well as the purchasers of their commodities. Pennsylvania may not choose to confound her interests in a connection so adverse to her policy. As she must at all events be a frontier, she will always have an army for its protection, and the government of that country must maintain it. She might defend herself against the Southern States; but if they should unite with those to the Northward of them, their force would be too great to be resisted. Pennsylvania in such an event would either submit or make a separate peace, which could hardly fail to prove highly injurious to her interests. It is therefore evident that all the Northern and Middle States must sooner or later unite into one confederacy for the purposes of defence against the Southern States.

If, in addition to the consideration of a plurality of civil lists, we take into view the number of persons who must necessarily be employed to guard the inland communication between the different confederacies against illicit trade, and who in time will infallibly spring up out of the necessities of revenue; and if we also take into view the military establishments which it has been shown would unavoidably result from the jealousies and conflicts of the several nations into which the States would be divided, we shall clearly discover that a separation would be not less injurious to the economy than to the tranquillity, commerce, revenue, and liberty of every part.

In these writings, Hamilton addresses several key themes: the inadequacies of the Articles of Confederation, the need for an effective national defense, and economic stability.

### Arguments Against the Weaknesses of the Confederation

Hamilton argues that the existing structure under the Articles of Confederal posed significant risks to both national security and governance. The decentralized power left too much authority with individual states, which often acted in their own interests rather than those of the union as a whole. He points out:

1. **Lack of Central Authority**: The Confederation lacked an executive branch or judiciary, limiting its ability to enforce laws or resolve disputes effectively.
2. **Ineffectiveness in National Defense**: Without a strong central government, states could not reliably coordinate defense efforts against external threats or internal insurrections.
3. **Economic Disarray**: States operated as independent entities with their own currencies and trade policies, leading to economic disunity and inefficiency.

Hamilton's writings emphasize that these weaknesses made it difficult for the nation to present a unified front in international relations and manage domestic affairs effectively.

### Need for a National Defense

One of Hamilton's principal concerns was national defense. He believed that only a centralized authority could ensure adequate protection against foreign threats or internal instability. Key points include:

- **Unified Military Command**: A strong federal government would provide a cohesive military strategy, ensuring states did not act independently to the detriment of national security.
- **Rapid Response Capability**: Centralized power would enable quicker mobilization and deployment of forces in response to crises.

Hamilton's arguments underscore that without a centralized defense system, the nation remained vulnerable to both external aggression and internal chaos.

### Economic Stability

Economic stability was another cornerstone of Hamilton's argument. He argued for federal control over economic policy as vital for national prosperity:

- **Uniform Currency**: A single national currency would facilitate trade and commerce between states.
- **Centralized Debt Management**: The federal government should assume state debts to stabilize the economy and establish creditworthiness on an international scale.

Hamilton believed that without a unified economic system, the nation risked financial ruin and economic fragmentation.

### Comparison with Modern Federal Systems

Comparing Hamilton's arguments to modern federal systems highlights both continuity and evolution in governance:

- **Federalism and Autonomy Balance**: While modern federations often balance power between national and regional governments more equitably than the U.S. under the Articles of Confederation, tensions between state and federal authorities remain common.

In summary, Alexander Hamilton’s writings in "The Federalist Papers" argue convincingly for a stronger federal system to overcome the weaknesses of the Articles of Confederation. His emphasis on national defense and economic stability remains relevant as foundational principles in modern federal systems, underscoring his lasting influence on political thought and governance structures.

text:
The View of the Constitution of the President Continued in Relation to the Mode of Appointment system, of any consequence, which has escaped without severe censure, or which has received the slightest mark of approbation from its opponents. The most plausible of these who has appeared in print has even deigned to admit that the election of the President is pretty well guarded. I venture somewhat further and hesitate not to affirm that if the manner of it be not perfect, it is at least excellent. It unites in an eminent degree all the advantages the union of which was to be wished for. It was desirable that the sense of the people should operate in the appointment of this officer, who will fill so important a station; and it was moreover thought reasonable, that as the executive magistracy is to be thus placed under the immediate authority of the people, the electors themselves should be chosen by them for the special purpose of making the election. This double use of the intervention of the people has been seen to have an interesting effect in our own State, where it was first introduced; and though not adopted precisely as here, yet with a deviation which does not impair its general principle. There, at each periodical election of members to the legislature, all the citizens who would be qualified electors of representatives in Congress on the first appointment under the Constitution, vote for such a number of persons as the whole number of senators and representatives allotted by the State may amount to; and these candidates are distinguished from the rest on the face of the return. The persons having the highest numbers of votes, not exceeding one half of the whole number of legislative appointments, become members of the Senate; and the persons who have the next greatest number of votes, not exceeding the residue of the legislative appointments, become members of the Assembly. It has not escaped observation that as an additional means of preventing turbulence and of ensuring good behavior in the senatorial body, two thirds are made a quorum for doing business. This idea might, perhaps, be adopted with propriety on the present occasion, as it is more essential to unanimity in the latter than in the former case. The constitution of this State has also thought fit to provide that if at any time a vacancy should happen in their Executive Council, during the recess of the legislature, the members of the Senate for the time being may elect a person from among themselves, or from the citizens at large, to supply it; and in case of an accidental defect of QUORUM, so as to prevent such election, the Governor is authorized to appoint a suitable person until the next meeting of the Senate. It is remarkable that in this, as in most other instances, the objection which is made would lie against the constitution of this State. We have a Lieutenant-Governor chosen by the people at large who presides in the Senate and is the constitutional substitute for the Governor in casualties similar to those which would authorize the Vice-President to exercise the authorities and discharge the duties of the President.

The advantages that will result from the principle of having the immediate election made by men chosen by the people for the special purpose, are as follows: it obviates the inconvenience felt in all indirect election where there is no principle of representation; as every member feels himself accountable to his constituents for every vote he gives. It would be otherwise if they were not thus specially delegated; and though a sense of public duty might control their conduct, yet the bias of party and local attachments would frequently give a different direction to it. It will exclude those violent and turbulent characters who too often disturb the harmony of public deliberations, and who being under no particular responsibility, may be tempted to commit to paper any thing which they think will make a figure in the public print or be magnified by a party leader.

It is evident that as these electors are chosen for the sole purpose of making the election, nothing can be more free than their agency; and it cannot well escape notice how wisely this mode is calculated to gratify at once the spirit of the people, and that jealousy which naturally exists against too great a portion of power lodged in any one set of men. The electors are to assemble in their respective States, and there vote by ballot for two persons, of whom one at least shall not be an inhabitant of the same State with themselves; thus eliminating all pretext for a preference of their own citizens, and in some degree linking together the different States by introducing into their partial concerns a regard to the rights and interests of others. That they cannot in any event give more than one vote to a citizen of the same State with themselves may have been thought an unnecessary precaution; but it is so obviously conformable to the principle which requires that no person shall be eligible as President who is not a natural born citizen or a citizen of the United States at the time of their adoption of the Constitution, and who has resided fourteen years within the limits thereof, that perhaps it could scarcely escape any body. This principle in regard to citizenship might have been so expressed as to have precluded a possibility of doubt whether the children of citizens born abroad or after the happening of certain events, were entitled to be admitted under the general description; but this was not thought necessary, because it is believed that no man who has a thorough conviction that these persons are citizens, will deny their eligibility. But another reason might have been assigned for requiring that one at least of the candidates voted by each elector should not be an inhabitant of his own State. It may well happen that in every State there will be some characters preeminent above all others in reputation and in services; men who have devoted long lives to the public weal, and signalized themselves as warriors or as patriots; great in war, great in peace, whose talents and virtues command general veneration. In such cases it is evident that if no other check existed, a man would be chosen from among them by every elector; which would amount to a virtual exclusion of all others, and make the appointment in fact devolve on the legislatures, who can have no legal power to direct the votes even of those electors whom they themselves may appoint. This is an inconvenience which could not escape observation, and which might be carried to such an extent as to produce consequences by no means desirous.

The next thing which claims our attention in this part of the system is the regulation for ascertaining the person who shall be President or Vice-President when it can be done only by counting the votes. This is a matter of considerable importance; and there are difficulties attending it which must have suggested to many some doubts of the propriety of leaving any thing of the kind to the legislature at all, instead of confiding it to the immediate agency of the electors themselves.

First, the legislature can only act in mass; they cannot go into partial investigations or enter into details. They must receive either the appointment as made by the people through their electors, or none at all. If they undertake to scrutinize and compare votes, what are the rules by which this is to be done? Are they to count them according to a priority of numbers without regard to characters, and thereby run the hazard (for example) of having the second person on the list chosen President in preference to one who may be more generally approved or more competent? Or if, in order to avoid this, they should enter into an examination of the votes with a view to select from among them the two who are most worthy; are they not exposed, by their very situation, to great temptations and strong prejudices which might mislead them to do what was really inconsistent both with justice and the public good? Suppose one State should have given its vote for A as President and B as Vice-President; another for B as President and C as Vice-President; and a third for C as President and A as Vice-President. If they are to choose from among these three candidates, is there no danger that local prejudices may mislead them to prefer one of their own citizens in preference to the others? This consideration has great weight with many who think it much safer to confide this trust to a select body whose interests will be more independent than those of an assembly acting by representation.

Secondly, as these persons are chosen for a specific and limited purpose, which is not likely to be repeated often, they can have no inducement to intrigue or cabal for office. The temptation arising from ambition could scarcely operate upon men thus circumstanced, because they would soon return into that private situation in society from which they had been taken; and if there were a probability of their being again called out of it, they might be supposed to have some interest in what should be done on the present occasion. But supposing them to be actuated by sinister views or influenced by improper connections, is not this an object more likely to engage attention in the primary assemblies where the members would probably be little known to each other, than in the legislature which would bring together a number of men who had been long upon the theatre of politics and whose characters would be well understood? In such situations they would find it difficult to conceal their views or to combine for any sinister purpose; and if detected, they could scarcely escape that severe censure which must always attend all attempts to betray a trust. It is not improbable that men may sometimes be found who would consent to prostitute the influence of their office to purposes of ambition by giving an undue bias to elections in favor of themselves or others; but where so many obstacles exist to such conduct, and where it can be so little concealed when committed, there will seldom be any thing more than a bare possibility of its taking place.

Thirdly, as they are not to enter upon the duties of their office until after the persons shall have been appointed in whose hands the executive power is to be vested, this regulation will serve as a bar even to indirect attempts at influencing elections which might otherwise be made by such men from considerations of interest. It would be difficult to say what degree of weight might be attached to such influences; but that they would be of some importance can scarcely be doubted.

Fourthly, it may be presumed that the members of this body will generally possess a superior information and discernment; because they will not only have been elected for that very purpose by men who are supposed to be capable of judging well where so important an object is concerned, but also because it may fairly be expected that those who are most distinguished for their knowledge and talents in the community will more commonly become objects of preference at such elections. This would seem to afford a solid foundation for presuming that they would act with greater wisdom than a body chosen by lot or taken indiscriminately from among the people.

Fifthly, as it is probable that a considerable proportion of them may be members of Congress themselves, there will always exist a connexion between the two branches of the government which cannot but be productive of important advantages. This connection will tend to preserve harmony and prevent any serious disagreements or collisions of authority; because they will have an interest in each other's prosperity and success, and will therefore be disposed to consult their mutual convenience and accommodation.

Lastly, it may be observed that this mode of proceeding is more consonant with the spirit of our constitution than the other. It has been remarked that it would seem to contradict the genius of republicanism for the same persons to exercise at one and the same time the offices both of electors and elected; because if they had a right to appoint others, they must have a right to appoint themselves also; which would be repugnant to all the principles of free government. The members of this body will therefore be considered as holding their office by virtue of an election made expressly for that purpose; so that there will be no inconsistency in allowing them to choose those who are to exercise authority over them.

In short, it may safely be affirmed that there is scarcely any objection which can with propriety be urged against leaving this trust in the hands of such a body. It appears to combine all those circumstances of safety and ability which constitute so desirable a recommendation for any public trust; while it avoids at the same time those inconveniences which must necessarily attend any other mode of proceeding.

Having thus stated what may be considered as some of the principal objections to this part of our system, we shall now proceed to notice a few of the advantages resulting from it. Among these we may mention:

First, the facility with which it can be carried into execution; for there is no danger of any violent opposition being made to it by those who are most interested in its success, since they will have been chosen expressly for that purpose and their appointment will therefore be considered as regular and legal.

Secondly, the certainty with which it will produce an effectual result. There can be little doubt but that this plan is likely to answer better than any other which has yet been proposed; because it will secure all those advantages which are necessary to ensure success, while at the same time it avoids many of the inconveniences and difficulties which have been found inseparable from other methods.

Thirdly, as it is not intended that these men shall exercise any authority themselves until after they have performed the duties for which they were appointed, this arrangement will prevent all possibility of their being influenced by personal considerations or prejudices. They will therefore be likely to act with perfect impartiality and fairness; which must be considered as a most essential circumstance in any election.

Fourthly, we may add that this mode of proceeding is attended with very little expense compared with others. It would indeed be difficult to find an institution so cheap yet so effectual in its operation as the one now under consideration.

Fifthly, and lastly, it is probable that if these men should ever become objects of envy or jealousy on account of their official station or influence, this circumstance might tend rather to increase than diminish their usefulness. They would find themselves surrounded by friends who were interested in promoting their welfare; while those who envied them would be likely to unite in efforts for the advancement of the public good which they had been so instrumental in securing.

From all these considerations it seems evident that there is nothing in this plan which can reasonably be objected to on any account whatever; but, on the contrary, every thing appears favorable to its adoption and execution. We have already shown that it is not only more safe than any other method, but also much more convenient and economical; and now we shall proceed to show that it is equally advantageous in respect of its probable consequences.

It may be remarked that there is scarcely any institution which has been adopted by man for regulating the affairs of society so perfectly consistent with those principles of justice and equity upon which all governments ought to be founded. It seems to combine, in a manner hitherto unknown, all those qualities which are necessary to render it completely satisfactory; while at the same time there appears scarcely any reason to apprehend any ill consequences from its operation.

One great advantage attending this mode of proceeding is that it tends very much to promote union among ourselves. We have already seen how many inconveniences and disadvantages must attend a separation between the different parts of our country, either in war or peace; and if we are desirous of avoiding those evils which may result from such an event, it cannot be denied that this is one of the most effectual means by which we can accomplish that end. By adopting this plan we shall have nothing to fear from any attempts on the part of foreign powers to excite dissensions among us or to take advantage of our weakness for their own aggrandizement; because we shall stand together as one nation, with all our strength united and concentrated under a single head. It is true that there may be circumstances in which some portions of the union might find it necessary to act separately from others; but if such should ever happen, this very circumstance would prove an additional security against any designs which might be entertained by our enemies for the subversion of our liberties.

### Disadvantages of Exclusion:

1. **Loss of Experience**: Excluding experienced individuals may lead to substituting inexperience with experience, potentially disrupting established administrative practices and reducing overall efficacy during critical times like war or national crises.

4. **Security Risks**: A popular official might resist stepping down if they have built strong support among the populace, potentially causing tension and unrest by opposing a system that prevents their continued service.

5. **Potential for Resentment**: Both leaders and citizens may view exclusion as an unnecessary restriction, leading to dissatisfaction and possibly undermining democratic principles of choice and representation.

1. **Increased Independence**: It is argued that leaders might act more independently if they are not concerned with securing re-election or future positions. However, this advantage is questionable, especially if the exclusion isn't perpetual.

2. **Enhanced Security for the People**: The idea here is to prevent any one person from accumulating too much power and influence over time. Yet, there's skepticism about whether such a measure truly enhances security, as it could provoke resistance from both leaders and their supporters.

### Conclusion:

The passage suggests that the disadvantages of exclusion—such as loss of experience, instability in governance, and potential insecurity—are more certain and significant than any speculative advantages like increased independence or enhanced security for the populace. "The Same View Continued in Relation to the Command of the National Forces and the Power: THE President of the United States is to be commander-in-chief of the army and navy of the United States, and of the militia of the several States when called into the actual service of the United States. The propriety of this provision is so evident in itself, and it is, at the same time, so consonant to the precedents of the State constitutions in general, that little need be said to explain or enforce it. Even those of them which have, in other respects, coupled the chief magistrate with a council, have for the most part concentrated the military authority in him alone. Of all the cares or concerns of government, the direction of war most peculiarly demands those qualities which distinguish the exercise of power by a single hand. The direction of war implies the direction of the common strength; and the power of directing and employing the common strength forms a usual and essential part in the definition of the executive authority. 'The President may require the opinion, in writing, of the principal officer in each of the executive departments upon any subject relating to the duties of their respective offices.' This I consider as a mere redundancy in the plan, as the right for which it provides would result of itself from the office. He is also to be authorized to grant 'reprieves and pardons for offenses against the United States, except in cases of impeachment.' Humanity and good policy conspire to dictate that the benign prerogative of pardoning should be as little as possible fettered or embarrassed. The criminal code of every country partakes so much of necessary severity, that without an easy access to exceptions in favor of unfortunate guilt, justice would wear a countenance too sanguinary and cruel. As the sense of responsibility is always strongest in proportion as it is undivided, it may be inferred that a single man would be most ready to attend to the force of those motives which might plead for a mitigation of the rigor of the law, and least apt to yield to considerations which were calculated to shelter a fit object of its vengeance. The reflection that the fate of a fellow-creature depended on his sole fiat, would naturally inspire scrupulousness and caution; the dread of being accused of weakness or connivance, would beget equal circumspection, though of a different kind. On the other hand, as men generally derive confidence from their numbers, they might often encourage each other in an act of obduracy, and might be less sensible to the apprehension of suspicion or censure for an injudicious or affected clemency. On these accounts, one man appears to be a more eligible dispenser of the mercy of government than a body of men.

The expediency of vesting the power of pardoning in the President has, if I mistake not, been only contested in relation to the crime of treason. This it has been urged ought to have depended upon the assent of one or both branches of the legislative body. I shall not deny that there are strong reasons to be assigned for requiring in this particular the concurrence of that body or of a part of it. As treason is a crime leveled at the immediate being of the society, when the laws have once ascertained the guilt of the offender, there seems a fitness in referring the expediency of an act of mercy towards him to the judgment of the legislature. And this ought the rather to be the case when policy demanded a conduct of forbearance and clemency. But the principal argument for reposing the power of pardoning in this case to the Chief Magistrate is that, in seasons of insurrection or rebellion, there are often critical moments when a well-timed offer of pardon to the insurgents or rebels may restore the tranquility of the commonwealth; and which if suffered to pass unimproved it may never be possible afterwards to recall. The dilatory process of convening the legislature, or one of its branches, for the purpose of obtaining its sanction to the measure, would frequently be the occasion of letting slip the golden opportunity. The loss of a week, a day, an hour, may sometimes be fatal. If it should be observed that a discretionary power with a view to such contingencies might be occasionally conferred upon the President, it may be answered in the first place that it is questionable whether, in a limited Constitution, that power could be delegated by law; and in the second place that it would generally be impolitic beforehand to take any step which might hold out the prospect of impunity. A proceeding of this kind, out of the usual course, would be likely to be construed into an argument of timidity or of weakness and would have a tendency to embolden guilt."

Here's your text formatted as a single continuous string with newlines and extra spaces removed:

"A Further View of the Judicial Department in Relation to the Provisions for the Support and Responsibility of the Judges NEXT to permanency in office, nothing can contribute more to the independence of the judges than a fixed provision for their support. The remark made in relation to the President is equally applicable here. In the general course of human nature, a power over a man's subsistence amounts to a power over his will. And we can never hope to see realized in practice, the complete separation of the judicial from the legislative power, in any system which leaves the former dependent for pecuniary resources on the occasional grants of the latter. The enlightened friends to good governments in every State have seen cause to lament the want of precise and explicit precautions in the State constitutions on this head. Some of these indeed have declared that permanent salaries should be established for the judges; but the experiment has in some instances shown that such expressions are not sufficiently definite to preclude legislative evasions. Something still more positive and unequivocal has been evidenced to be requisite. The plan of the convention accordingly has provided that the judges of the United States 'shall at stated times receive for their services a compensation which shall not be diminished during their continuance in office.' This, all circumstances considered, is the most eligible provision that could have been devised. It will readily be understood that the fluctuations in the value of money and in the state of society rendered a fixed rate of compensation in the Constitution inadmissible. What might be extravagant today might in half a century become penurious and inadequate. It was therefore necessary to leave it to the discretion of the legislature to vary its provisions in conformity to the variations in circumstances, yet under such restrictions as to put it out of the power of that body to change the condition of the individual for the worse. A man may then be sure of the ground upon which he stands and can never be deterred from his duty by the apprehension of being placed in a less eligible situation. The clause which has been quoted combines both advantages. The salaries of judicial officers may from time to time be altered, as occasion shall require, yet so as never to lessen the allowance with which any particular judge comes into office, in respect to him. It will be observed that a difference has been made by the convention between the compensation of the President and of the judges. That of the former can neither be increased nor diminished; that of the latter can only not be diminished. This probably arose from the difference in the duration of the respective offices. As the President is to be elected for no more than four years, it can rarely happen that an adequate salary fixed at the commencement of that period will not continue to be such to its end. But with regard to the judges, who, if they behave properly, will be secured in their places for life, it may well happen, especially in the early stages of the government, that a stipend which would be very sufficient at their first appointment, would become too small in the progress of their service. Vide 'Constitution of Massachusetts,' Chapter 2, section 1, article 13. This provision for the support of the judges bears every mark of prudence and efficacy; and it may be safely affirmed that, together with the permanent tenure of their offices, it affords a better prospect of their independence than is discoverable in the constitutions of any of the States in regard to their own judges. The precautions for their responsibility are comprised in the article respecting impeachments. The constitution of New York, to avoid investigations that must forever be vague and dangerous, has taken a particular age as the criterion of inability. No man can be a judge beyond sixty. I believe there are few at present who do not disapprove of this provision. There is no station in relation to which it is less proper than to that of a judge. The deliberating and comparing faculties generally preserve their strength much beyond that period in men who survive it; and when, in addition to this circumstance, we consider how few there are who outlive the season of intellectual vigor, and how improbably it is that any considerable portion of the bench, whether more or less numerous, should be in such a situation at the same time, we shall be ready to conclude that limitations of this sort have little to recommend them. In a republic where fortunes are not affluent, and pensions not expedient, the dismission of men from stations in which they have served their country long and usefully, on which they depend for subsistence, and from which it will be too late to resort to any other occupation for a livelihood, ought to have some better apology to humanity than is to be found in the imaginary danger of a superannuated bench."
